user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_shared_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_shared_response (void *cls,
                        struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                        const char *url,
                        const char *method,
                        const char *version,
                        const char *upload_data,
                        size_t *upload_data_size,
                        void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  unsigned int resp_index;
  static volatile unsigned int last_index = 0;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

  /* This kind of operation does not guarantee that numbers are not reused
     in parallel threads, when processed simultaneously, but this should not
     be a big problem, as it just slow down replies a bit due to
     responses locking. */
  resp_index = (last_index++) % num_resps;
  return MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, resps[resp_index]);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are present in the provided code. In particular, the code does not use any of the common compiler extensions that are typically documented as extensions (e.g. GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __asm__ tokens, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, asm volatile, __builtin_* intrinsics, or any vendor-specific keywords). The constructs used are standard C: function-local static variables, volatile, pointer casts (void *) and standard library types (size_t), enum return type, string comparisons, and the modulus/post-increment operations. The MHD_* identifiers are library macros/types (from libmicrohttpd) and not language extensions themselves. Therefore there are no code fragments requiring investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions should not be used).
